events.text_segment:
Next moment we were both groping downstairs, leaving the candle by the empty chest; and the next we had opened the door and were in full retreat. We had not started a moment too soon. The fog was rapidly dispersing; already the moon shone quite clear on the high ground on either side; and it was only in the exact bottom of the dell and round the tavern door that a thin veil still hung unbroken to conceal the first steps of our escape. Far less than half-way to the hamlet, very little beyond the bottom of the hill, we must come forth into the moonlight. Nor was this all, for the sound of several footsteps running came already to our ears, and as we looked back in their direction, a light tossing to and fro and still rapidly advancing showed that one of the newcomers carried a lantern.
“My dear,” said my mother suddenly, “take the money and run on. I am going to faint.”
This was certainly the end for both of us, I thought. How I cursed the cowardice of the neighbours; how I blamed my poor mother for her honesty and her greed, for her past foolhardiness and present weakness! We were just at the little bridge, by good fortune; and I helped her, tottering as she was, to the edge of the bank, where, sure enough, she gave a sigh and fell on my shoulder. I do not know how I found the strength to do it at all, and I am afraid it was roughly done, but I managed to drag her down the bank and a little way under the arch. Farther I could not move her, for the bridge was too low to let me do more than crawl below it. So there we had to stay—my mother almost entirely exposed and both of us within earshot of the inn.

events.title: The Buccaneers' Arrival and Initial Search of the Inn
detailed_summary: Driven by curiosity over fear, the narrator returns to a vantage point overlooking the inn.
He witnesses the arrival of seven or eight men, led by one with a lantern, running erratically.
He recognizes the blind beggar, Pew, among them, confirmed by his voice.
Pew orders his men to break down the inn door.
The men rush the Admiral Benbow, but pause, surprised to find the door already open.
Pew, impatient and enraged, shouts for them to enter immediately.
Four or five men go inside, while two stay with Pew on the road.
A cry of surprise is heard from the inn, followed by the announcement that Bill is deceased.
Pew angrily commands some to search the body and others to go upstairs for the chest.
The narrator hears the men rushing up the stairs.
Sounds of astonishment follow, the captain's room window is forcefully opened, breaking glass, and a man addresses Pew from above.
The man reports that others have preceded them and searched the chest thoroughly.

events.text_segment:
My curiosity, in a sense, was stronger than my fear, for I could not remain where I was, but crept back to the bank again, whence, sheltering my head behind a bush of broom, I might command the road before our door. I was scarcely in position ere my enemies began to arrive, seven or eight of them, running hard, their feet beating out of time along the road and the man with the lantern some paces in front. Three men ran together, hand in hand; and I made out, even through the mist, that the middle man of this trio was the blind beggar. The next moment his voice showed me that I was right.
“Down with the door!” he cried.
“Aye, aye, sir!” answered two or three; and a rush was made upon the Admiral Benbow, the lantern-bearer following; and then I could see them pause, and hear speeches passed in a lower key, as if they were surprised to find the door open. But the pause was brief, for the blind man again issued his commands. His voice sounded louder and higher, as if he were afire with eagerness and rage.
“In, in, in!” he shouted, and cursed them for their delay.
Four or five of them obeyed at once, two remaining on the road with the formidable beggar. There was a pause, then a cry of surprise, and then a voice shouting from the house, “Bill’s dead.”
But the blind man swore at them again for their delay.
“Search him, some of you shirking lubbers, and the rest of you aloft and get the chest,” he cried.
I could hear their feet rattling up our old stairs, so that the house must have shook with it. Promptly afterwards, fresh sounds of astonishment arose; the window of the captain’s room was thrown open with a slam and a jingle of broken glass, and a man leaned out into the moonlight, head and shoulders, and addressed the blind beggar on the road below him.
“Pew,” he cried, “they’ve been before us. Someone’s turned the chest out alow and aloft.”

events.title: Pew's Frustration Over the Missing 'Flint's Fist'
detailed_summary: Pew bellows, asking if the desired item is in the chest.
The man at the window confirms that the money is still there.
Pew curses the money, clarifying that he is looking for 'Flint's fist'.
The man replies that they cannot find 'Flint's fist' anywhere.
Pew then asks if the item is on Bill's body.
Another pirate, likely the one searching Bill, comes to the inn door and reports that Bill has already been thoroughly searched and nothing was left on him.
Pew expresses extreme frustration, blaming the inn's occupants, specifically 'that boy' (the narrator), and wishes he had blinded him.
He reasons that the occupants couldn't have gone far, as the door was bolted when he tried it earlier.
He orders his men to scatter and find them, noting they must have left their light source behind.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Scatter and find ’em! Rout the house out!” reiterated Pew, striking with his stick upon the road.

events.text_segment:
“Is it there?” roared Pew.
“The money’s there.”
The blind man cursed the money.
“Flint’s fist, I mean,” he cried.
“We don’t see it here nohow,” returned the man.
“Here, you below there, is it on Bill?” cried the blind man again.
At that another fellow, probably him who had remained below to search the captain’s body, came to the door of the inn. “Bill’s been overhauled a’ready,” said he; “nothin’ left.”
“It’s these people of the inn—it’s that boy. I wish I had put his eyes out!” cried the blind man, Pew. “There were no time ago—they had the door bolted when I tried it. Scatter, lads, and find ’em.”
“Sure enough, they left their glim here,” said the fellow from the window.
“Scatter and find ’em! Rout the house out!” reiterated Pew, striking with his stick upon the road.

“Is it there?” roared Pew.

The man at the window, who had been rummaging in the chest, drew back the lid and peered in. “The money’s there,” he said.

“Curse the money!” cried Pew. “I don’t want the money. I want Flint’s papers. Do you hear? Flint’s papers!”

The man at the window shook his head. “We’ve looked everywhere, Pew, and we can’t find them.”

“Is it on Bill’s body?”

A second man came to the door, and with a grunt of exertion, he pushed it open. “Bill’s been stripped to the skin,” he said. “There’s not a rag left on him.”

Pew’s face was a mass of fury. “Then where is it?” he hissed. “Where is it? I’ll tear the house down before I go. I’ll have it, or I’ll have the life out of that boy!”

He turned to his men. “They couldn’t have gone far,” he muttered. “I tried the door myself not five minutes ago, and it was bolted. They must be hiding somewhere in the house.”

He gave a sudden, fierce laugh. “They’ve left the lantern behind,” he said. “That’s a good sign. Now, you men, scatter and find them!”

Then there followed a great to-do through all our old inn, heavy feet pounding to and fro, furniture thrown over, doors kicked in, until the very rocks re-echoed and the men came out again, one after another, on the road and declared that we were nowhere to be found. And just the same whistle that had alarmed my mother and myself over the dead captain’s money was once more clearly audible through the night, but this time twice repeated. I had thought it to be the blind man’s trumpet, so to speak, summoning his crew to the assault, but I now found that it was a signal from the hillside towards the hamlet, and from its effect upon the buccaneers, a signal to warn them of approaching danger.
“There’s Dirk again,” said one. “Twice! We’ll have to budge, mates.”
“Budge, you skulk!” cried Pew. “Dirk was a fool and a coward from the first—you wouldn’t mind him. They must be close by; they can’t be far; you have your hands on it. Scatter and look for them, dogs! Oh, shiver my soul,” he cried, “if I had eyes!”

This appeal seemed to produce some effect, for two of the fellows began to look here and there among the lumber, but half-heartedly, I thought, and with half an eye to their own danger all the time, while the rest stood irresolute on the road.
“You have your hands on thousands, you fools, and you hang a leg! You’d be as rich as kings if you could find it, and you know it’s here, and you stand there skulking. There wasn’t one of you dared face Bill, and I did it—a blind man! And I’m to lose my chance for you! I’m to be a poor, crawling beggar, sponging for rum, when I might be rolling in a coach! If you had the pluck of a weevil in a biscuit you would catch them still.”
“Hang it, Pew, we’ve got the doubloons!” grumbled one.
“They might have hid the blessed thing,” said another. “Take the Georges, Pew, and don’t stand here squalling.”
Squalling was the word for it; Pew’s anger rose so high at these objections till at last, his passion completely taking the upper hand, he struck at them right and left in his blindness and his stick sounded heavily on more than one.
These, in their turn, cursed back at the blind miscreant, threatened him in horrid terms, and tried in vain to catch the stick and wrest it from his grasp.

events.title: Arrival of Rescuers, Pirates' Flight, and Pew's Violent Death
detailed_summary: The internal conflict among the pirates proves to be a fortunate turn for the narrator and his mother.
The dispute is interrupted by the distinct sound of approaching horses at a gallop from the hamlet hill, followed by a pistol shot from the hedge.

Pew, left alone, moves frantically along the road, calling out names like Johnny, Black Dog, and Dirk, pleading not to be deserted.
He mistakenly heads towards the hamlet, directly into the path of the oncoming riders.
Upon seeing the four or five moonlit riders charging down the slope, Pew realizes his error, screams, and attempts to dive into a ditch.
He quickly regains his feet but, utterly disoriented, dashes right under the closest approaching horse.

This quarrel was the saving of us, for while it was still raging, another sound came from the top of the hill on the side of the hamlet—the tramp of horses galloping. Almost at the same time a pistol-shot, flash and report, came from the hedge side. And that was plainly the last signal of danger, for the buccaneers turned at once and ran, separating in every direction, one seaward along the cove, one slant across the hill, and so on, so that in half a minute not a sign of them remained but Pew. Him they had deserted, whether in sheer panic or out of revenge for his ill words and blows I know not; but there he remained behind, tapping up and down the road in a frenzy, and groping and calling for his comrades. Finally he took a wrong turn and ran a few steps past me, towards the hamlet, crying, “Johnny, Black Dog, Dirk,” and other names, “you won’t leave old Pew, mates—not old Pew!”
Just then the noise of horses topped the rise, and four or five riders came in sight in the moonlight and swept at full gallop down the slope.
At this Pew saw his error, turned with a scream, and ran straight for the ditch, into which he rolled. But he was on his feet again in a second and made another dash, now utterly bewildered, right under the nearest of the coming horses.
The rider tried to save him, but in vain. Down went Pew with a cry that rang high into the night; and the four hoofs trampled and spurned him and passed by. He fell on his side, then gently collapsed upon his face and moved no more.

events.text_segment:
I leaped to my feet and hailed the riders. They were pulling up, at any rate, horrified at the accident; and I soon saw what they were. One, tailing out behind the rest, was a lad that had gone from the hamlet to Dr. Livesey’s; the rest were revenue officers, whom he had met by the way, and with whom he had had the intelligence to return at once. Some news of the lugger in Kitt’s Hole had found its way to Supervisor Dance and set him forth that night in our direction, and to that circumstance my mother and I owed our preservation from death.
Pew was dead, stone dead. As for my mother, when we had carried her up to the hamlet, a little cold water and salts and that soon brought her back again, and she was none the worse for her terror, though she still continued to deplore the balance of the money. In the meantime the supervisor rode on, as fast as he could, to Kitt’s Hole; but his men had to dismount and grope down the dingle, leading, and sometimes supporting, their horses, and in continual fear of ambushes; so it was no great matter for surprise that when they got down to the Hole the lugger was already under way, though still close in. He hailed her. A voice replied, telling him to keep out of the moonlight or he would get some lead in him, and at the same time a bullet whistled close by his arm. Soon after, the lugger doubled the point and disappeared. Mr. Dance stood there, as he said, “like a fish out of water,” and all he could do was to dispatch a man to B—— to warn the cutter. “And that,” said he, “is just about as good as nothing. They’ve got off clean, and there’s an end. Only,” he added, “I’m glad I trod on Master Pew’s corns,” for by this time he had heard my story.

I knew then that our lives would never be the same again.

We rode hard all the way till we drew up before Dr. Livesey’s door. The house was all dark to the front.
Mr. Dance told me to jump down and knock, and Dogger gave me a stirrup to descend by. The door was opened almost at once by the maid.
“Is Dr. Livesey in?” I asked.
No, she said, he had come home in the afternoon but had gone up to the hall to dine and pass the evening with the squire.
“So there we go, boys,” said Mr. Dance.
This time, as the distance was short, I did not mount, but ran with Dogger’s stirrup-leather to the lodge gates and up the long, leafless, moonlit avenue to where the white line of the hall buildings looked on either hand on great old gardens. Here Mr. Dance dismounted, and taking me along with him, was admitted at a word into the house.
The servant led us down a matted passage and showed us at the end into a great library, all lined with bookcases and busts upon the top of them, where the squire and Dr. Livesey sat, pipe in hand, on either side of a bright fire.

events.text_segment:
I had never seen the squire so near at hand. He was a tall man, over six feet high, and broad in proportion, and he had a bluff, rough-and-ready face, all roughened and reddened and lined in his long travels. His eyebrows were very black, and moved readily, and this gave him a look of some temper, not bad, you would say, but quick and high.
“Come in, Mr. Dance,” says he, very stately and condescending.
“Good evening, Dance,” says the doctor with a nod. “And good evening to you, friend Jim. What good wind brings you here?”
The supervisor stood up straight and stiff and told his story like a lesson; and you should have seen how the two gentlemen leaned forward and looked at each other, and forgot to smoke in their surprise and interest. When they heard how my mother went back to the inn, Dr. Livesey fairly slapped his thigh, and the squire cried “Bravo!” and broke his long pipe against the grate. Long before it was done, Mr. Trelawney (that, you will remember, was the squire’s name) had got up from his seat and was striding about the room, and the doctor, as if to hear the better, had taken off his powdered wig and sat there looking very strange indeed with his own close-cropped black poll.
At last Mr. Dance finished the story.

events.title: Aftermath of the Story: Praise, Plans, and the Mysterious Packet
detailed_summary: The squire commended Mr. Dance for his bravery, likening his pursuit of the pirate to a virtuous act of pest control.
He also expressed a positive impression of Jim Hawkins, calling him a 'trump,' and instructed Jim to ring for ale for Mr. Dance.
Dr. Livesey then questioned Jim, asking if he possessed the item that the attackers had been seeking.
Jim confirmed he did and handed the oilskin packet to the doctor.
Dr. Livesey examined the packet, appearing eager to open it, but chose instead to place it securely in his coat pocket.
The doctor informed the squire that while Mr. Dance needed to depart on official duties after his ale, he intended for Jim Hawkins to stay overnight at his house.
He also proposed, with the squire's consent, that they provide Jim with a cold pie for supper.
The squire readily agreed, stating that Jim deserved something better than a mere cold pie for his efforts.
Subsequently, a substantial pigeon pie was served to Jim, who ate with great appetite due to his hunger, while Mr. Dance received additional praise before being allowed to leave.

events.text_segment:
“Mr. Dance,” said the squire, “you are a very noble fellow. And as for riding down that black, atrocious miscreant, I regard it as an act of virtue, sir, like stamping on a cockroach. This lad Hawkins is a trump, I perceive. Hawkins, will you ring that bell? Mr. Dance must have some ale.”
“And so, Jim,” said the doctor, “you have the thing that they were after, have you?”
“Here it is, sir,” said I, and gave him the oilskin packet.
The doctor looked it all over, as if his fingers were itching to open it; but instead of doing that, he put it quietly in the pocket of his coat.
“Squire,” said he, “when Dance has had his ale he must, of course, be off on his Majesty’s service; but I mean to keep Jim Hawkins here to sleep at my house, and with your permission, I propose we should have up the cold pie and let him sup.”
“As you will, Livesey,” said the squire; “Hawkins has earned better than cold pie.”
So a big pigeon pie was brought in and put on a sidetable, and I made a hearty supper, for I was as hungry as a hawk, while Mr. Dance was further complimented and at last dismissed.

“Mr. Dance,” said the squire, “you are a very noble fellow. You have done a gallant thing, and I call it a Christian thing, to go in pursuit of those villains. It is like killing a wasp, which may have stung you, but which you kill all the same, because it is a wasp. You are a trump, Mr. Dance, and I shall not forget it.”

He then turned to me with a smile. “And as for you, Jim Hawkins, you are a trump too. Ring the bell, my lad, and bring in the ale for Mr. Dance.”

Dr. Livesey, who had been standing a little apart, now stepped forward and laid a hand on my shoulder. “Jim,” he said, “do you still have the thing they were after?”

I nodded and drew the oilskin packet from my pocket. He took it with a kind of reverence, and though I thought he was going to open it at once, he only looked at it for a moment, then put it carefully into his own coat pocket.

“Mr. Dance,” he said, “I am sorry to say you must be off again. But Jim is to stay the night with me, and I hope you will not mind a cold pie for supper.”

The squire laughed. “A cold pie! Why, the boy has earned a feast. He has earned a gold piece, and I shall give it to him when the time comes.”

So it was settled. A great pigeon pie was brought in, and I ate it with a will, for I was very hungry. Mr. Dance, after a few more words of praise, was dismissed, and the squire and the doctor sat down to talk over the business of the map and the treasure.

Dr. Livesey, who had been standing a little apart, now stepped forward and laid a hand on my shoulder. “Jim,” he said, “do you still have the thing they were after?”

I nodded and drew the oilskin packet from my pocket. He took it with a kind of reverence, and though I thought he was going to open it at once, he only looked at it for a moment, then put it carefully into his own coat pocket.

“Mr. Dance,” he said, “I am sorry to say you must be off again. But Jim is to stay the night with me, and I hope you will not mind a cold pie for supper.”

The squire laughed. “A cold pie! Why, the boy has earned a feast. He has earned a gold piece, and I shall give it to him when the time comes.”

So it was settled. A great pigeon pie was brought in, and I ate it with a will, for I was very hungry. Mr. Dance, after a few more words of praise, was dismissed, and the squire and the doctor sat down to talk over the business of the map and the treasure.

“And now, squire,” said the doctor.
“And now, Livesey,” said the squire in the same breath.
“One at a time, one at a time,” laughed Dr. Livesey. “You have heard of this Flint, I suppose?”
“Heard of him!” cried the squire. “Heard of him, you say! He was the bloodthirstiest buccaneer that sailed. Blackbeard was a child to Flint. The Spaniards were so prodigiously afraid of him that, I tell you, sir, I was sometimes proud he was an Englishman. I’ve seen his top-sails with these eyes, off Trinidad, and the cowardly son of a rum-puncheon that I sailed with put back—put back, sir, into Port of Spain.”
“Well, I’ve heard of him myself, in England,” said the doctor. “But the point is, had he money?”
“Money!” cried the squire. “Have you heard the story? What were these villains after but money? What do they care for but money? For what would they risk their rascal carcasses but money?”
“That we shall soon know,” replied the doctor. “But you are so confoundedly hot-headed and exclamatory that I cannot get a word in. What I want to know is this: Supposing that I have here in my pocket some clue to where Flint buried his treasure, will that treasure amount to much?”
“Amount, sir!” cried the squire. “It will amount to this: If we have the clue you talk about, I fit out a ship in Bristol dock, and take you and Hawkins here along, and I’ll have that treasure if I search a year.”
“Very well,” said the doctor. “Now, then, if Jim is agreeable, we’ll open the packet”; and he laid it before him on the table.

events.text_segment:
The bundle was sewn together, and the doctor had to get out his instrument case and cut the stitches with his medical scissors. It contained two things—a book and a sealed paper.
“First of all we’ll try the book,” observed the doctor.
The squire and I were both peering over his shoulder as he opened it, for Dr. Livesey had kindly motioned me to come round from the side-table, where I had been eating, to enjoy the sport of the search. On the first page there were only some scraps of writing, such as a man with a pen in his hand might make for idleness or practice. One was the same as the tattoo mark, “Billy Bones his fancy”; then there was “Mr. W. Bones, mate,” “No more rum,” “Off Palm Key he got itt,” and some other snatches, mostly single words and unintelligible. I could not help wondering who it was that had “got itt,” and what “itt” was that he got. A knife in his back as like as not.
“Not much instruction there,” said Dr. Livesey as he passed on.
The next ten or twelve pages were filled with a curious series of entries. There was a date at one end of the line and at the other a sum of money, as in common account-books, but instead of explanatory writing, only a varying number of crosses between the two. On the 12th of June, 1745, for instance, a sum of seventy pounds had plainly become due to someone, and there was nothing but six crosses to explain the cause. In a few cases, to be sure, the name of a place would be added, as “Offe Caraccas,” or a mere entry of latitude and longitude, as “62° 17′ 20″, 19° 2′ 40″.”
The record lasted over nearly twenty years, the amount of the separate entries growing larger as time went on, and at the end a grand total had been made out after five or six wrong additions, and these words appended, “Bones, his pile.”
“I can’t make head or tail of this,” said Dr. Livesey.
“The thing is as clear as noonday,” cried the squire. “This is the black-hearted hound’s account-book. These crosses stand for the names of ships or towns that they sank or plundered. The sums are the scoundrel’s share, and where he feared an ambiguity, you see he added something clearer. ‘Offe Caraccas,’ now; you see, here was some unhappy vessel boarded off that coast. God help the poor souls that manned her—coral long ago.”
“Right!” said the doctor. “See what it is to be a traveller. Right! And the amounts increase, you see, as he rose in rank.”

events.title: Unveiling the Treasure Map and Its Secrets
detailed_summary: The account book contained little more beyond some navigational bearings written on blank pages near the end and a conversion table for French, English, and Spanish currencies.
Dr. Livesey remarked on the pirate's thriftiness, suggesting he was not one to be swindled.
The squire then urged them to examine the other item, the sealed paper.
The paper had been secured in multiple places using a thimble as a makeshift seal, which Jim thought might be the same thimble he found in the captain's pocket.
Dr. Livesey meticulously opened the seals, revealing a map of an island.

The map included detailed information such as latitude and longitude, water depths (soundings), names of geographical features like hills, bays, and inlets, and all necessary details for a ship to anchor safely.

The island was described as approximately nine miles long and five miles wide, with a shape resembling an upright, stout dragon. It featured two well-protected harbors and a central hill named 'The Spy-glass.'
Several later additions were visible on the map, most notably three crosses marked in red ink: two in the northern part of the island and one in the southwest.
Next to the southwestern cross, written in the same red ink but in a small, neat handwriting distinct from the captain's unsteady script, were the words: 'Bulk of treasure here.'

On the reverse side of the map, the same neat handwriting provided further instructions: 'Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.'

Additional directions indicated that bar silver was located in a 'north cache,' discoverable by following the trend of an eastern hummock, ten fathoms south of a black crag with a facial feature. Arms were to be found in a sand-hill at the north point of a north inlet cape, bearing E. and a quarter N., initialed 'J.F.'
Although these concise instructions were baffling to Jim, they brought immense joy to both the squire and Dr. Livesey.

“Thrifty man!” cried the doctor. “He wasn’t the one to be cheated.”

Over on the back the same hand had written this further information: Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet. The arms are easy found, in the sand-hill, N. point of north inlet cape, bearing E. and a quarter N. J.F.
That was all; but brief as it was, and to me incomprehensible, it filled the squire and Dr. Livesey with delight.

events.text_segment:
“Livesey,” said the squire, “you will give up this wretched practice at once. Tomorrow I start for Bristol. In three weeks’ time—three weeks!—two weeks—ten days—we’ll have the best ship, sir, and the choicest crew in England. Hawkins shall come as cabin-boy. You’ll make a famous cabin-boy, Hawkins. You, Livesey, are ship’s doctor; I am admiral. We’ll take Redruth, Joyce, and Hunter. We’ll have favourable winds, a quick passage, and not the least difficulty in finding the spot, and money to eat, to roll in, to play duck and drake with ever after.”
“Trelawney,” said the doctor, “I’ll go with you; and I’ll go bail for it, so will Jim, and be a credit to the undertaking. There’s only one man I’m afraid of.”
“And who’s that?” cried the squire. “Name the dog, sir!”
“You,” replied the doctor; “for you cannot hold your tongue. We are not the only men who know of this paper. These fellows who attacked the inn tonight—bold, desperate blades, for sure—and the rest who stayed aboard that lugger, and more, I dare say, not far off, are, one and all, through thick and thin, bound that they’ll get that money. We must none of us go alone till we get to sea. Jim and I shall stick together in the meanwhile; you’ll take Joyce and Hunter when you ride to Bristol, and from first to last, not one of us must breathe a word of what we’ve found.”

events.title: Prolonged Anticipation and Imaginative Explorations
detailed_summary: The preparations for the sea journey took considerably more time than initially anticipated, causing disruptions to their original plans, including Dr. Livesey's idea to keep Jim close by.
Dr. Livesey was compelled to travel to London to arrange for another physician to manage his medical practice in his absence.
The Squire was deeply engrossed in work at Bristol.

Jim remained at the Hall under the care of old Redruth, the gamekeeper, feeling somewhat confined but simultaneously filled with vivid dreams of the sea and exciting expectations of unfamiliar islands and thrilling escapades.
He would spend extensive periods poring over the map, committing all its features to memory.

While sitting by the fire in the housekeeper's room, he mentally explored the island from every conceivable angle, traversed every part of its terrain, and imagined himself countless times ascending the prominent hill known as the Spy-glass, from which he envisioned spectacular and ever-changing views.

His imaginative scenarios varied: sometimes the island teemed with hostile natives they had to battle, other times it was populated by perilous beasts that pursued them; yet, none of his fantasies were as bizarre or heartbreaking as the reality of their forthcoming experiences.

The doctor had to go to London for a physician to take charge of his practice; the squire was hard at work at Bristol; and I lived on at the hall under the charge of old Redruth, the gamekeeper, almost a prisoner, but full of sea-dreams and the most charming anticipations of strange islands and adventures. I brooded by the hour together over the map, all the details of which I well remembered. Sitting by the fire in the housekeeper’s room, I approached that island in my fancy from every possible direction; I explored every acre of its surface; I climbed a thousand times to that tall hill they call the Spy-glass, and from the top enjoyed the most wonderful and changing prospects. Sometimes the isle was thick with savages, with whom we fought, sometimes full of dangerous animals that hunted us, but in all my fancies nothing occurred to me so strange and tragic as our actual adventures.

events.title: Squire Trelawney's Letter: Ship Acquired and Crew Assembled
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney's letter, dated from Bristol, informed Dr. Livesey that the ship, a fine 200-ton schooner named *Hispaniola*, had been purchased and fully prepared for their voyage.

The Squire attributed the successful acquisition of the ship to his old friend Blandly, whom he praised as exceptionally helpful, despite acknowledging that some Bristol locals harbored strong prejudices against Blandly, even accusing him of overcharging for the *Hispaniola*.
He noted that the people of Bristol became remarkably cooperative once word spread that their destination involved treasure.
During the reading, Jim interrupted to express concern to Redruth that Dr. Livesey would disapprove of the Squire openly discussing the treasure, but Redruth defended the Squire's prerogative.
The Squire continued in his letter, admitting that while the shipwrights were slow, the primary challenge had been assembling a suitable crew of about twenty men.

He described a stroke of luck: a chance meeting on the dock with an old sailor, Long John Silver, who ran a public-house, knew all the seafarers in Bristol, and desired a cook's position on a ship to improve his health after time ashore.
The Squire was deeply moved by Silver's story, especially learning he had lost his leg in service to his country under Admiral Hawke and received no pension, prompting him to hire Silver on the spot.
Silver turned out to be more than just a cook; he was instrumental in gathering a formidable crew of seasoned sailors, whom the Squire described as rugged but incredibly spirited.
Long John Silver also advised the Squire to dismiss two of the initially hired men, deeming them unsuitable for such a significant undertaking.
The Squire concluded this part of his letter by expressing his own excellent well-being and immense eagerness for the voyage to begin.

events.text_segment:
Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—.
Dear Livesey—As I do not know whether you are at the hall or still in London, I send this in double to both places.
The ship is bought and fitted. She lies at anchor, ready for sea. You never imagined a sweeter schooner—a child might sail her—two hundred tons; name, Hispaniola.
I got her through my old friend, Blandly, who has proved himself throughout the most surprising trump. The admirable fellow literally slaved in my interest, and so, I may say, did everyone in Bristol, as soon as they got wind of the port we sailed for—treasure, I mean.
“Redruth,” said I, interrupting the letter, “Dr. Livesey will not like that. The squire has been talking, after all.”
“Well, who’s a better right?” growled the gamekeeper. “A pretty rum go if squire ain’t to talk for Dr. Livesey, I should think.”
At that I gave up all attempts at commentary and read straight on:
Blandly himself found the Hispaniola, and by the most admirable management got her for the merest trifle. There is a class of men in Bristol monstrously prejudiced against Blandly. They go the length of declaring that this honest creature would do anything for money, that the Hispaniola belonged to him, and that he sold it me absurdly high—the most transparent calumnies. None of them dare, however, to deny the merits of the ship.
So far there was not a hitch. The workpeople, to be sure—riggers and what not—were most annoyingly slow; but time cured that. It was the crew that troubled me.
I wished a round score of men—in case of natives, buccaneers, or the odious French—and I had the worry of the deuce itself to find so much as half a dozen, till the most remarkable stroke of fortune brought me the very man that I required.
I was standing on the dock, when, by the merest accident, I fell in talk with him. I found he was an old sailor, kept a public-house, knew all the seafaring men in Bristol, had lost his health ashore, and wanted a good berth as cook to get to sea again. He had hobbled down there that morning, he said, to get a smell of the salt.
I was monstrously touched—so would you have been—and, out of pure pity, I engaged him on the spot to be ship’s cook. Long John Silver, he is called, and has lost a leg; but that I regarded as a recommendation, since he lost it in his country’s service, under the immortal Hawke. He has no pension, Livesey. Imagine the abominable age we live in!
Well, sir, I thought I had only found a cook, but it was a crew I had discovered. Between Silver and myself we got together in a few days a company of the toughest old salts imaginable—not pretty to look at, but fellows, by their faces, of the most indomitable spirit. I declare we could fight a frigate.
Long John even got rid of two out of the six or seven I had already engaged. He showed me in a moment that they were just the sort of fresh-water swabs we had to fear in an adventure of importance.
I am in the most magnificent health and spirits, eating like a bull, sleeping like a tree, yet I shall not enjoy a moment till I hear my old tarpaulins tramping round the capstan.

Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—.

I have just returned from a most extraordinary meeting with a man who claims to have sailed with Captain Flint himself. His name is Billy Bones, and he is a retired seaman, now living in the care of the widow Hawkins, who keeps this inn. He is a man of great age and even greater stories, though he is clearly troubled by something. He speaks in riddles and warnings, and his manner is most peculiar. He has a sea chest locked with a key that he keeps close to his person, and he is always looking over his shoulder as if expecting someone to follow him.

I was introduced to him by the widow, who told me that he had once been a mate on the ship *His Majesty’s sloop Wasp*, and that he had served under the infamous Captain Flint. He has a map, he says, of a certain island where a vast treasure is hidden, and he is looking for a young man to accompany him on a voyage to find it. He has been searching for such a man for some time, and he believes I may be the one. I must admit, the idea of such a journey is most tempting, though I am not yet certain of the man’s intentions.

Billy Bones is not the only one with secrets. The widow Hawkins, too, seems to know more than she lets on. She has a son, Jim, who is a boy of about thirteen, and she treats him with great care and affection. I have noticed that she often speaks to him in hushed tones and that he, too, seems to be listening for something. I suspect that the boy may have a role to play in this strange business, though I do not yet know what it is.

The man’s stories are wild and full of danger, but they are also filled with a strange kind of poetry. He speaks of the sea as if it were a living thing, and of the treasure as if it were a dream. He has a way of making the impossible seem possible, and the dangerous seem exciting. I find myself drawn to him, though I am also wary. He is a man who has seen much of the world and much of its cruelty, and I fear that he may have lost something of himself in the process.

I have agreed to meet with him again tomorrow, and I shall see what more he has to say. I must be careful, for I have the feeling that this is no ordinary adventure. There is something about Billy Bones and his map that sets my mind racing and my heart pounding. I can only hope that I am not walking into a trap, for I have a feeling that once I step onto this path, there will be no turning back.

events.title: Further Instructions, Postscript Details, and Jim's Exuberance
detailed_summary: The Squire passionately urged Dr. Livesey to hasten to Bristol, exclaiming his current obsession was with the allure of the sea rather than the treasure itself.
He directed that young Hawkins should visit his mother, escorted by Redruth, before both of them proceeded swiftly to Bristol.
A postscript added that Blandly was arranged to send a support vessel if their party didn't return by August's end, and had also found an excellent, though rather formal, sailing master.
Long John Silver had also recruited a very capable mate named Arrow, and the ship even had a boatswain who used a pipe, indicating things would be run in a disciplined, naval style.

Another forgotten detail shared was that Silver was a man of some means, with a consistently solvent bank account. He was leaving his wife, a woman of color, to manage his inn, leading the Squire to jest that perhaps his wife, as much as his health, was his reason for returning to sea.
A final, brief postscript permitted Hawkins to spend one night with his mother.
This letter threw Jim into a state of extreme excitement and happiness.
He felt a strong disdain for old Tom Redruth, who could only complain and express regret about the situation.
While other under-gamekeepers would have eagerly taken Redruth's place, the Squire's preferences were treated as absolute commands, and only Redruth possessed the audacity to grumble.

Seaward, ho! Hang the treasure! It’s the glory of the sea that has turned my head. So now, Livesey, come post; do not lose an hour, if you respect me.
Let young Hawkins go at once to see his mother, with Redruth for a guard; and then both come full speed to Bristol. John Trelawney
Postscript.—I did not tell you that Blandly, who, by the way, is to send a consort after us if we don’t turn up by the end of August, had found an admirable fellow for sailing master—a stiff man, which I regret, but in all other respects a treasure. Long John Silver unearthed a very competent man for a mate, a man named Arrow. I have a boatswain who pipes, Livesey; so things shall go man-o’-war fashion on board the good ship Hispaniola.
I forgot to tell you that Silver is a man of substance; I know of my own knowledge that he has a banker’s account, which has never been overdrawn. He leaves his wife to manage the inn; and as she is a woman of colour, a pair of old bachelors like you and I may be excused for guessing that it is the wife, quite as much as the health, that sends him back to roving.
P.P.S.—Hawkins may stay one night with his mother.
You can fancy the excitement into which that letter put me. I was half beside myself with glee; and if ever I despised a man, it was old Tom Redruth, who could do nothing but grumble and lament. Any of the under-gamekeepers would gladly have changed places with him; but such was not the squire’s pleasure, and the squire’s pleasure was like law among them all. Nobody but old Redruth would have dared so much as even to grumble.

events.title: A Bittersweet Farewell to Home and Mother
detailed_summary: The following day, Jim and Redruth journeyed on foot to the Admiral Benbow.
Jim was relieved to find his mother in good health and cheerful. The disruptive captain who had caused so much trouble was no longer a concern.
The Squire had funded various improvements: the inn was repaired, public areas and the sign repainted, and new furniture added, notably a comfortable armchair for Jim's mother in the bar.
The Squire had also arranged for an apprentice boy to assist her during Jim's absence.
It was the sight of this new boy that made Jim, for the first time, truly comprehend the reality of his departure and the home he was leaving behind.
Until that moment, his thoughts had been consumed by the adventures ahead, but seeing this unfamiliar boy who would take his place beside his mother brought on his first bout of tears.
Jim confesses he treated the new apprentice harshly, frequently correcting and belittling him, partly due to his own emotional state and the boy's inexperience.
After spending the night, Jim and Redruth set off again the next day following their midday meal.
Jim bid farewell to his mother, the familiar cove of his birth, and the Admiral Benbow, which felt slightly less dear to him after its repainting.
A final thought drifted to the deceased captain, whom he often pictured walking the beach with his distinctive hat, facial scar, and brass telescope.

events.text_segment:
The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits. The captain, who had so long been a cause of so much discomfort, was gone where the wicked cease from troubling. The squire had had everything repaired, and the public rooms and the sign repainted, and had added some furniture—above all a beautiful armchair for mother in the bar. He had found her a boy as an apprentice also so that she should not want help while I was gone.
It was on seeing that boy that I understood, for the first time, my situation. I had thought up to that moment of the adventures before me, not at all of the home that I was leaving; and now, at sight of this clumsy stranger, who was to stay here in my place beside my mother, I had my first attack of tears. I am afraid I led that boy a dog’s life, for as he was new to the work, I had a hundred opportunities of setting him right and putting him down, and I was not slow to profit by them.
The night passed, and the next day, after dinner, Redruth and I were afoot again and on the road. I said good-bye to Mother and the cove where I had lived since I was born, and the dear old Admiral Benbow—since he was repainted, no longer quite so dear. One of my last thoughts was of the captain, who had so often strode along the beach with his cocked hat, his sabre-cut cheek, and his old brass telescope.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits. The old captain was gone, and with him all the uneasiness and terror that had so long hung over us. The Squire had been at great expense to put the house in order; the bar was newly furnished, the sign repainted, and the rooms within made clean and comfortable. He had also provided my mother with a new armchair, which she was very proud of, and had sent for an apprentice boy to help her about the house while I was away. It was when I saw this boy, a strange, quiet lad, that I first began to feel the weight of my going. I had been so taken up with the business of the ship and the voyage, and the thought of the gold and the island, that I had not yet thought of myself. But now, as I looked at the boy standing by the fire, and thought of the long months I should be away, I felt a great lump rise in my throat, and I turned my face to the wall to hide my tears. I was not a bit proud of it, but I could not help it. I had been very hard upon the boy, and had scolded him for everything he did, and I believe I frightened him more than I need have done. The next day, after a night of uneasy sleep, we set out again, and I left my mother and the Admiral Benbow behind me. I looked back once or twice as we went down the hill, and the place seemed less dear to me now that it was painted and made new. But I could not help thinking of the old captain, and how he used to walk the beach with his hat on one side, and his face all scarred, and his brass telescope in his hand.

And so, with the memory of Treasure Island still fresh in my mind, I continued on my journey, a true sailor at heart.

events.title: The Journey to Bristol by Mail Coach
detailed_summary: Shortly after departing, Jim's childhood home vanished from his view as they rounded a bend.
Around dusk, they were picked up by the mail coach at an inn called the Royal George, located on the heath.
Jim found himself positioned between Redruth and a portly elderly gentleman during the coach ride.
Despite the swift movement of the coach and the chill of the night air, Jim quickly fell asleep and remained so for the majority of the journey, through various stages and terrains.
He was finally roused by a poke in his side, opening his eyes to discover they were stationary in front of a large building on a city street, and that day had broken some time ago.

events.text_segment:
Next moment we had turned the corner and my home was out of sight.
The mail picked us up about dusk at the Royal George on the heath. I was wedged in between Redruth and a stout old gentleman, and in spite of the swift motion and the cold night air, I must have dozed a great deal from the very first, and then slept like a log up hill and down dale through stage after stage, for when I was awakened at last it was by a punch in the ribs, and I opened my eyes to find that we were standing still before a large building in a city street and that the day had already broken a long time.
“Where are we?” I asked.

I had not been in the coach five minutes before I found myself between Tom Redruth and a stout old gentleman, who, I afterwards learned, was a Justice of the Peace. We were not long in starting, and soon the road began to rise, and we were rattling over the heath at a great rate. The night was cold and the wind was high, but I was so tired and sleepy that I had not been in the coach above a quarter of an hour before I was fast asleep. I do not know how long I slept, but I was waked by a poke in the side, and found the coach stopped, and a great many people about it, and the day quite come. detailed_summary: Jim Hawkins receives a note from Squire Trelawney to deliver to John Silver at the Spy-glass tavern.
Filled with anticipation to see more of the maritime environment, Jim navigates the crowded and bustling docks.

When I had done breakfasting the squire gave me a note addressed to John Silver, at the sign of the Spy-glass, and told me I should easily find the place by following the line of the docks and keeping a bright lookout for a little tavern with a large brass telescope for sign. I set off, overjoyed at this opportunity to see some more of the ships and seamen, and picked my way among a great crowd of people and carts and bales, for the dock was now at its busiest, until I found the tavern in question.
It was a bright enough little place of entertainment. The sign was newly painted; the windows had neat red curtains; the floor was cleanly sanded. There was a street on each side and an open door on both, which made the large, low room pretty clear to see in, in spite of clouds of tobacco smoke.
The customers were mostly seafaring men, and they talked so loudly that I hung at the door, almost afraid to enter.

I was uncommonly pleased with the commission, for I had a great mind to see more of the seafaring world, and I had heard of the Spy-glass before as a place where all the best hands in the island used to meet. So I set off with a light heart, and after a little wandering, I came at last to the docks, which were a great scene of life and bustle, with ships and boats of all sorts, and men shouting and running about, and the air full of the smell of tar and salt water.

I kept a sharp look-out for the Spy-glass, and at last I saw it, a little way off, with the brass telescope shining in the sun. It was a neat little tavern, freshly painted, with red curtains at the windows, and the floor inside was clean and sanded. The doors were open on both sides of the long, low room, and the smoke of a hundred pipes made the air thick and yellow, but the light came in freely, and I could see the faces of the men who were sitting at the tables or leaning against the bar.

They were all seafaring men, rough and loud, and they were talking in a way that made me stop and listen, though I did not like to go in just yet. I stood at the door for a minute, feeling rather shy, for I was not used to such company, and I thought I should be afraid of them if I went in. But I had my errand, and I knew I must go on, so I took a deep breath and stepped inside.

events.title: First Encounter with Long John Silver
detailed_summary: As Jim hesitates, a man emerges from a side room, and Jim is immediately certain this must be Long John Silver.

He is a tall, strong man with a large, plain, and pale face, which nonetheless conveys intelligence and a smile.
He appears to be in high spirits, whistling as he moves among the tables, offering cheerful words or a friendly slap on the shoulder to his favored patrons.
Jim reflects on his earlier fear that Long John might be the one-legged pirate he had been wary of at the Admiral Benbow.
However, the sight of this clean, pleasant-tempered landlord dispels Jim's apprehension, as he seems markedly different from the buccaneers (Captain, Black Dog, Pew) Jim had previously encountered.
Mustering his courage, Jim crosses the threshold and walks directly to Long John, who is propped on his crutch conversing with a customer.
Jim addresses him as Mr. Silver and hands over the note.

events.text_segment:
As I was waiting, a man came out of a side room, and at a glance I was sure he must be Long John. His left leg was cut off close by the hip, and under the left shoulder he carried a crutch, which he managed with wonderful dexterity, hopping about upon it like a bird. He was very tall and strong, with a face as big as a ham—plain and pale, but intelligent and smiling. Indeed, he seemed in the most cheerful spirits, whistling as he moved about among the tables, with a merry word or a slap on the shoulder for the more favoured of his guests.
Now, to tell you the truth, from the very first mention of Long John in Squire Trelawney’s letter I had taken a fear in my mind that he might prove to be the very one-legged sailor whom I had watched for so long at the old Benbow. But one look at the man before me was enough. I had seen the captain, and Black Dog, and the blind man, Pew, and I thought I knew what a buccaneer was like—a very different creature, according to me, from this clean and pleasant-tempered landlord.
I plucked up courage at once, crossed the threshold, and walked right up to the man where he stood, propped on his crutch, talking to a customer.
“Mr. Silver, sir?” I asked, holding out the note.
“Yes, my lad,” said he; “such is my name, to be sure. And who may you be?” And then as he saw the squire’s letter, he seemed to me to give something almost like a start.
“Oh!” said he, quite loud, and offering his hand. “I see. You are our new cabin-boy; pleased I am to see you.”
And he took my hand in his large firm grasp.

events.title: Black Dog's Unexpected Appearance and Flight
detailed_summary: At that moment, a customer from the far side of the room abruptly gets up and makes a dash for the door, quickly disappearing into the street.
The man's hurried departure catches Jim's attention, and he instantly recognizes him as the pale-faced man missing two fingers, Black Dog, who had previously visited the Admiral Benbow.

Jim reiterates that it was Black Dog and asks if Mr. Trelawney hadn't informed Silver about the buccaneers, confirming Black Dog was one of them.

Just then one of the customers at the far side rose suddenly and made for the door. It was close by him, and he was out in the street in a moment. But his hurry had attracted my notice, and I recognized him at glance. It was the tallow-faced man, wanting two fingers, who had come first to the Admiral Benbow.
“Oh,” I cried, “stop him! It’s Black Dog!”
“I don’t care two coppers who he is,” cried Silver. “But he hasn’t paid his score. Harry, run and catch him.”

events.title: Silver's Cunning Interrogation and Deception of Jim
detailed_summary: Morgan, an elderly, grey-haired sailor with a weather-beaten face, approaches Silver rather sheepishly, chewing on his tobacco.
Long John sternly questions Morgan, who denies having ever seen Black Dog before or knowing his name, punctuating his denial with a salute.

Silver warns Morgan that it's fortunate for him he wasn't truly acquainted with Black Dog, threatening that he would have been barred from the tavern otherwise, and then presses Morgan about their conversation.
Morgan claims he doesn't rightly know what they were discussing.
Long John berates Morgan for his lack of awareness, sarcastically questioning his intelligence, and demands to know the topic of their conversation—voyages, captains, ships.
Morgan replies that they were talking about keel-hauling.
Silver sardonically agrees it's a suitable topic for Morgan and dismisses him back to his seat, calling him a lubber.
As Morgan retreats, Silver whispers confidentially to Jim, in a manner Jim finds flattering, that Morgan is an honest man, just unintelligent.
Silver then aloud feigns difficulty recalling the name Black Dog, but then pretends to remember seeing him with a blind beggar.
Jim confirms this and adds that he knew the blind man, whose name was Pew.

Silver reacts with apparent excitement to the name Pew, remarking on his shark-like appearance and expressing eagerness to capture Black Dog for Captain Trelawney, praising Ben's running abilities and vowing to 'keel-haul' Black Dog himself.
Throughout this performance, Silver moves animatedly, slapping tables and displaying such convincing excitement that Jim notes it would have fooled legal authorities.
Jim's earlier suspicions, rekindled by finding Black Dog at the Spy-glass, lead him to watch Silver closely, but Silver's depth, readiness, and cleverness are too much for Jim.

By the time the two pursuers return breathless, confessing they lost Black Dog in a crowd and are subsequently scolded by Silver, Jim is so thoroughly deceived that he would have vouched for Long John Silver's innocence.

events.text_segment:
The man whom he called Morgan—an old, grey-haired, mahogany-faced sailor—came forward pretty sheepishly, rolling his quid.
“Now, Morgan,” said Long John very sternly, “you never clapped your eyes on that Black—Black Dog before, did you, now?”
“Not I, sir,” said Morgan with a salute.
“You didn’t know his name, did you?”
“No, sir.”
“By the powers, Tom Morgan, it’s as good for you!” exclaimed the landlord. “If you had been mixed up with the like of that, you would never have put another foot in my house, you may lay to that. And what was he saying to you?”
“I don’t rightly know, sir,” answered Morgan.
“Do you call that a head on your shoulders, or a blessed dead-eye?” cried Long John. “Don’t rightly know, don’t you! Perhaps you don’t happen to rightly know who you was speaking to, perhaps? Come, now, what was he jawing—v’yages, cap’ns, ships? Pipe up! What was it?”
“We was a-talkin’ of keel-hauling,” answered Morgan.
“Keel-hauling, was you? And a mighty suitable thing, too, and you may lay to that. Get back to your place for a lubber, Tom.”
And then, as Morgan rolled back to his seat, Silver added to me in a confidential whisper that was very flattering, as I thought, “He’s quite an honest man, Tom Morgan, on’y stupid. And now,” he ran on again, aloud, “let’s see—Black Dog? No, I don’t know the name, not I. Yet I kind of think I’ve—yes, I’ve seen the swab. He used to come here with a blind beggar, he used.”
“That he did, you may be sure,” said I. “I knew that blind man too. His name was Pew.”
“It was!” cried Silver, now quite excited. “Pew! That were his name for certain. Ah, he looked a shark, he did! If we run down this Black Dog, now, there’ll be news for Cap’n Trelawney! Ben’s a good runner; few seamen run better than Ben. He should run him down, hand over hand, by the powers! He talked o’ keel-hauling, did he? I’ll keel-haul him!”
All the time he was jerking out these phrases he was stumping up and down the tavern on his crutch, slapping tables with his hand, and giving such a show of excitement as would have convinced an Old Bailey judge or a Bow Street runner. My suspicions had been thoroughly reawakened on finding Black Dog at the Spy-glass, and I watched the cook narrowly. But he was too deep, and too ready, and too clever for me, and by the time the two men had come back out of breath and confessed that they had lost the track in a crowd, and been scolded like thieves, I would have gone bail for the innocence of Long John Silver.

The man whom he called Morgan—an old, grey-haired, mahogany-faced sailor—came forward pretty sheepishly, rolling his quid. 

"Well, now," says Long John, "you've been talking to Black Dog, I suppose?"

"Black Dog, sir," returned Morgan, with a sort of respectful confusion, "I never heard on him in my life."

"You wouldn't, perhaps, know him if you saw him?"

"I should not, sir."

"You wouldn't know his name, perhaps, if you heard it?"

"I should not, sir."

"You're a fool, Morgan," said Silver, with a grin, "but you're a fool with a sense of self-preservation. I'm not going to quarrel with you for not knowing Black Dog. But I want to know what you were talking about with him."

"I don't rightly know, sir," said Morgan, with a shrug.

"You don't rightly know!" repeated Silver, with a sneer. "You don't rightly know what you were talking about with a man you've never heard of, and whose name you don't know!"

"It was about keel-hauling, sir," said Morgan, after a pause.

"Ah!" said Silver, with a nod. "That's a subject for you, Morgan. That's a subject for a lubber like you."

He turned to me, and whispered in a confidential tone, as if he were telling me a great secret: "He's an honest man, Jim, but he's a fool."

Then he turned back to the table, and said aloud, as if to himself: "Black Dog—Black Dog—what was his name again?"

"He was with the blind beggar," I said.

"Ah!" said Silver, with a sudden start. "The blind beggar! That's the man I want to see."

"His name was Pew," I said.

"Pew!" said Silver, with a sort of shudder. "A shark, that man."

He got up and began to walk about the room, with a great deal of animation, and slapped the table with his hand, and made a great show of being excited. He said he would go and find Black Dog for Captain Trelawney, and that he would keel-haul him himself. He said he had heard of a man named Ben who could run like the wind, and that he would catch Black Dog yet.

It was all a performance, but it was a good one. I could see that Silver was trying to make me believe in his innocence, and I could see that he was doing it with a great deal of skill. I had my suspicions, of course, for I had seen Black Dog at the Spy-glass, and I knew that Silver had been in the habit of meeting him there. But Silver was too deep for me. He was too ready, too clever. He had a way of making me believe in him that I could not help.

When the two men came back, breathless and out of countenance, and said that they had lost Black Dog in the crowd, Silver turned on them with a fury that was almost convincing. He scolded them, and threatened them, and said that he would have them flogged if they did not do better next time. And I, for my part, was so thoroughly deceived that I would have given my word for Long John Silver's innocence.

Billy Bones, the captain of the Hispaniola, had once been his shipmate, and it was from him that Jim had first heard the name of the one-legged seaman, Long John Silver.

Morgan's face was a map of wrinkles and weather, each line carved by years of salt and wind. His eyes, though dimmed by age, still held a glint of the old fire, the fire of a man who had seen more than he had ever spoken of. He had a habit of muttering to himself, as if the sea had left him with a few words too many and he was trying to sort them out.

Jim, who had been watching the old sailor with a mix of curiosity and caution, stepped forward. "You're the one Billy Bones spoke of," he said, his voice steady but his heart pounding. "The one who knows the way to Treasure Island."

Morgan looked up, his eyes narrowing slightly. He chewed his quid for a moment, then spat into the sand. "Aye, lad, I know the way," he said, his voice rough as the sea in a storm. "But the way is not for the faint of heart."

Jim nodded, his resolve hardening. He had heard the stories of the mutiny, of the treasure buried deep in the heart of the island, and of the one-legged seaman who had once been a friend to all and a foe to none. He had also heard the warnings, the tales of men who had gone in search of the treasure and never returned.

Morgan studied him for a long moment, then gave a slow nod. "You're a brave lad," he said. "But bravery alone won't get you far. You'll need a map, a crew, and a head for danger."

Jim's heart sank slightly at the thought of the challenges ahead, but he straightened his shoulders. "I have the map," he said, pulling it from his coat. "And I'll find the crew."

Morgan took the map, his fingers tracing the lines and symbols with the care of a man who had once drawn them himself. He looked up, his eyes meeting Jim's with a strange mix of pride and sorrow. "Then you're off to a good start, lad. But remember, the sea is a fickle mistress, and the island is a cruel master."

Jim nodded, the weight of the journey settling on his shoulders. He had set out to find a treasure, but he was beginning to realize that the real treasure might be the journey itself.

events.title: Silver's Calculated Lament and Shared Merriment with Jim
detailed_summary: Silver addresses Jim, lamenting the difficult situation Black Dog's escape has placed him in, particularly concerning Captain Trelawney's likely opinion.
He complains about the audacity of Black Dog sitting in his establishment, drinking his rum, and then managing to escape despite Jim plainly identifying him.
Silver pleads for Jim to represent him fairly to the captain, acknowledging Jim's youth but praising his astuteness.
He emphasizes his helplessness due to his wooden leg, claiming that in his prime as an able-bodied master mariner, he would have swiftly apprehended Black Dog.
Suddenly, Silver stops, his jaw dropping as if a crucial thought has just struck him.
He exclaims about Black Dog's unpaid bill for three measures of rum, feigning astonishment at having forgotten it.
He then collapses onto a bench, laughing until tears stream down his face. Jim cannot help but join in, and they laugh together boisterously until the tavern resounds.
Wiping his cheeks, Silver self-deprecatingly calls himself a 'precious old sea-calf' and suggests that he and Jim will get on well, humorously proposing he should be rated as a ship's boy.
He then abruptly shifts to a serious demeanor, stating that 'duty is duty' and they must go to Captain Trelawney to report the incident.

Silver acknowledges the seriousness of the matter and that neither of them has emerged from it with credit, then laughs heartily again about the unpaid score, compelling Jim to join in his mirth once more, despite not fully grasping the joke as Silver does.

“See here, now, Hawkins,” said he, “here’s a blessed hard thing on a man like me, now, ain’t it? There’s Cap’n Trelawney—what’s he to think? Here I have this confounded son of a Dutchman sitting in my own house drinking of my own rum! Here you comes and tells me of it plain; and here I let him give us all the slip before my blessed deadlights! Now, Hawkins, you do me justice with the cap’n. You’re a lad, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when you first come in. Now, here it is: What could I do, with this old timber I hobble on? When I was an A B master mariner I’d have come up alongside of him, hand over hand, and broached him to in a brace of old shakes, I would; but now—”
And then, all of a sudden, he stopped, and his jaw dropped as though he had remembered something.
“The score!” he burst out. “Three goes o’ rum! Why, shiver my timbers, if I hadn’t forgotten my score!”
And falling on a bench, he laughed until the tears ran down his cheeks. I could not help joining, and we laughed together, peal after peal, until the tavern rang again.
“Why, what a precious old sea-calf I am!” he said at last, wiping his cheeks. “You and me should get on well, Hawkins, for I’ll take my davy I should be rated ship’s boy. But come now, stand by to go about. This won’t do. Dooty is dooty, messmates. I’ll put on my old cockerel hat, and step along of you to Cap’n Trelawney, and report this here affair. For mind you, it’s serious, young Hawkins; and neither you nor me’s come out of it with what I should make so bold as to call credit. Nor you neither, says you; not smart—none of the pair of us smart. But dash my buttons! That was a good un about my score.”
And he began to laugh again, and that so heartily, that though I did not see the joke as he did, I was again obliged to join him in his mirth.

“See here, now, Hawkins,” said he, “here’s a blessed hard thing on a man like me, now, ain’t it? Black Dog, with one hand, and me with one leg—what’s the odds? He sat down on the settle and took a long pull at his rum. “It’s a hard case,” he went on, “and I don’t see how I’m to get out of it. That Black Dog, he’s a bold one, I must say. Sits in my own house, drinks my rum, and then goes off and leaves me to the blame. And you, Hawkins, you see him plain as day, and yet he gets away. It’s a shame, it is.”

He looked at me with a kind of wistful, appealing look, and I felt a little sorry for him. “You’re a young man, Hawkins,” he said, “and I don’t suppose you’ve got much of a head for these things. But you’re sharp, and I know you’ll do me justice. I’ve always treated you fair, and I’ve always looked out for you.”

He leaned forward and tapped the table with his knuckles. “I was a master mariner once, and I could have caught that Black Dog with one hand tied behind me. But now, with this here leg, I’m no good. I can’t run, I can’t fight, I can’t do nothing but sit and drink rum and talk.”

He stopped suddenly, his face lighting up with a new idea. “Three measures of rum!” he cried. “Three measures of rum, and I never thought of it! That’s what he owes me, Hawkins. Three measures of rum, and I’ve let it go. I’ve let it go, and I’ve been a fool!”

He collapsed into a chair and began to laugh, a great, rolling laugh that shook the whole room. I couldn’t help it—I joined in, and soon the whole tavern was ringing with our laughter. Silver wiped his eyes with the back of his hand and called himself a “precious old sea-calf.”

“Now, Hawkins,” he said, “I think we’ll get on well together. I’ll be a good ship’s boy to you, and you’ll be a good master to me.”

Then he sobered up all at once. “Duty is duty,” he said, “and we’ve got to go and tell Trelawney. It’s a serious matter, and neither of us has come out of it with credit. But I’ll tell you what, Hawkins—” He laughed again, and I laughed with him, though I didn’t see the joke as clearly as he did. “I’ll tell you what, Hawkins,” he said, “I think I’ll mention that three measures of rum.”

He identifies the various ships they pass, explaining details about their rigging, tonnage, and country of origin.

The Hispaniola lay some way out, and we went under the figureheads and round the sterns of many other ships, and their cables sometimes grated underneath our keel, and sometimes swung above us. At last, however, we got alongside, and were met and saluted as we stepped aboard by the mate, Mr. Arrow, a brown old sailor with earrings in his ears and a squint. He and the squire were very thick and friendly, but I soon observed that things were not the same between Mr. Trelawney and the captain.
This last was a sharp-looking man who seemed angry with everything on board and was soon to tell us why, for we had hardly got down into the cabin when a sailor followed us.
“Captain Smollett, sir, axing to speak with you,” said he.
“I am always at the captain’s orders. Show him in,” said the squire.
The captain, who was close behind his messenger, entered at once and shut the door behind him.

events.title: Captain Smollett's Unveiled Discontent
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney initiates the conversation, asking Captain Smollett for his assessment of the ship and preparations.
Captain Smollett responds directly and bluntly, stating his dissatisfaction with the cruise, the crew, and his officer, Mr. Arrow.
Squire Trelawney, visibly angered, challenges Smollett, questioning if he also dislikes the ship and, implicitly, his employer.
Dr. Livesey calmly intervenes, advising against questions likely to cause ill feeling and insists that Smollett must elaborate on his stark pronouncements.
Smollett explains that he was hired under "sealed orders" but has discovered that every crew member below officer rank is better informed about the voyage's details than he is, which he deems unfair.
He reveals that he has learned from his own men that the voyage is a treasure hunt.

Smollett expresses his deep apprehension about treasure voyages in general, particularly those that are meant to be secret but have clearly been compromised, alluding to the widespread knowledge by suggesting the secret was "told to the parrot."
He concludes by stating his belief that neither Trelawney nor Livesey fully comprehend the severe risks involved, which he characterizes as a matter of life or death.

events.text_segment:
“Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?”
“Well, sir,” said the captain, “better speak plain, I believe, even at the risk of offence. I don’t like this cruise; I don’t like the men; and I don’t like my officer. That’s short and sweet.”
“Perhaps, sir, you don’t like the ship?” inquired the squire, very angry, as I could see.
“I can’t speak as to that, sir, not having seen her tried,” said the captain. “She seems a clever craft; more I can’t say.”
“Possibly, sir, you may not like your employer, either?” says the squire.
But here Dr. Livesey cut in.
“Stay a bit,” said he, “stay a bit. No use of such questions as that but to produce ill feeling. The captain has said too much or he has said too little, and I’m bound to say that I require an explanation of his words. You don’t, you say, like this cruise. Now, why?”
“I was engaged, sir, on what we call sealed orders, to sail this ship for that gentleman where he should bid me,” said the captain. “So far so good. But now I find that every man before the mast knows more than I do. I don’t call that fair, now, do you?”
“No,” said Dr. Livesey, “I don’t.”
“Next,” said the captain, “I learn we are going after treasure—hear it from my own hands, mind you. Now, treasure is ticklish work; I don’t like treasure voyages on any account, and I don’t like them, above all, when they are secret and when (begging your pardon, Mr. Trelawney) the secret has been told to the parrot.”
“Silver’s parrot?” asked the squire.
“It’s a way of speaking,” said the captain. “Blabbed, I mean. It’s my belief neither of you gentlemen know what you are about, but I’ll tell you my way of it—life or death, and a close run.”

“That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey. “We take the risk, but we are not so ignorant as you believe us. Next, you say you don’t like the crew. Are they not good seamen?”
“I don’t like them, sir,” returned Captain Smollett. “And I think I should have had the choosing of my own hands, if you go to that.”
“Perhaps you should,” replied the doctor. “My friend should, perhaps, have taken you along with him; but the slight, if there be one, was unintentional. And you don’t like Mr. Arrow?”
“I don’t, sir. I believe he’s a good seaman, but he’s too free with the crew to be a good officer. A mate should keep himself to himself—shouldn’t drink with the men before the mast!”
“Do you mean he drinks?” cried the squire.
“No, sir,” replied the captain, “only that he’s too familiar.”
“Well, now, and the short and long of it, captain?” asked the doctor. “Tell us what you want.”
“Well, gentlemen, are you determined to go on this cruise?”
“Like iron,” answered the squire.
“Very good,” said the captain. “Then, as you’ve heard me very patiently, saying things that I could not prove, hear me a few words more. They are putting the powder and the arms in the fore hold. Now, you have a good place under the cabin; why not put them there?—first point. Then, you are bringing four of your own people with you, and they tell me some of them are to be berthed forward. Why not give them the berths here beside the cabin?—second point.”
“Any more?” asked Mr. Trelawney.
“One more,” said the captain. “There’s been too much blabbing already.”
“Far too much,” agreed the doctor.
“I’ll tell you what I’ve heard myself,” continued Captain Smollett: “that you have a map of an island, that there’s crosses on the map to show where treasure is, and that the island lies—” And then he named the latitude and longitude exactly.
“I never told that,” cried the squire, “to a soul!”
“The hands know it, sir,” returned the captain.
“Livesey, that must have been you or Hawkins,” cried the squire.
“It doesn’t much matter who it was,” replied the doctor. And I could see that neither he nor the captain paid much regard to Mr. Trelawney’s protestations. Neither did I, to be sure, he was so loose a talker; yet in this case I believe he was really right and that nobody had told the situation of the island.

“Good,” said Dr. Livesey. “And now, we must decide what to do next. We cannot stay here forever, and we cannot let the pirates get the better of us. We must find the treasure before they do.”

Just then, there was a knock at the door. Dr. Livesey and Jim exchanged a quick glance before the doctor went to answer it. It was Squire Trelawney, looking pale and worried.

“Doctor,” he said, “we have a problem. The pirates have taken the ship and are preparing to leave. They mean to take the treasure and leave us behind.”

Dr. Livesey’s face darkened. “Then we must act quickly. Jim, you must go to the stockade and warn the others. Tell them what we have learned and that we must move at once.”

Jim hesitated. “But what if they catch me?”

“They won’t if you are careful,” said Dr. Livesey. “Now go, and may God be with you.”

Jim ran out into the night, heart pounding. He knew the danger he was in, but he also knew that he had to do his part. The treasure was out there, and so were the pirates. It was a race against time, and Jim was determined to win.

“Well, gentlemen,” continued the captain, “I don’t know who has this map; but I make it a point, it shall be kept secret even from me and Mr. Arrow. Otherwise I would ask you to let me resign.”
“I see,” said the doctor. “You wish us to keep this matter dark and to make a garrison of the stern part of the ship, manned with my friend’s own people, and provided with all the arms and powder on board. In other words, you fear a mutiny.”
“Sir,” said Captain Smollett, “with no intention to take offence, I deny your right to put words into my mouth. No captain, sir, would be justified in going to sea at all if he had ground enough to say that. As for Mr. Arrow, I believe him thoroughly honest; some of the men are the same; all may be for what I know. But I am responsible for the ship’s safety and the life of every man Jack aboard of her. I see things going, as I think, not quite right. And I ask you to take certain precautions or let me resign my berth. And that’s all.”
“Captain Smollett,” began the doctor with a smile, “did ever you hear the fable of the mountain and the mouse? You’ll excuse me, I dare say, but you remind me of that fable. When you came in here, I’ll stake my wig, you meant more than this.”
“Doctor,” said the captain, “you are smart. When I came in here I meant to get discharged. I had no thought that Mr. Trelawney would hear a word.”
“No more I would,” cried the squire. “Had Livesey not been here I should have seen you to the deuce. As it is, I have heard you. I will do as you desire, but I think the worse of you.”
“That’s as you please, sir,” said the captain. “You’ll find I do my duty.”
And with that he took his leave.

“Trelawney,” said the doctor, “contrary to all my notions, I believed you have managed to get two honest men on board with you—that man and John Silver.”
“Silver, if you like,” cried the squire; “but as for that intolerable humbug, I declare I think his conduct unmanly, unsailorly, and downright un-English.”
“Well,” says the doctor, “we shall see.”
When we came on deck, the men had begun already to take out the arms and powder, yo-ho-ing at their work, while the captain and Mr. Arrow stood by superintending.
The new arrangement was quite to my liking. The whole schooner had been overhauled; six berths had been made astern out of what had been the after-part of the main hold; and this set of cabins was only joined to the galley and forecastle by a sparred passage on the port side. It had been originally meant that the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire were to occupy these six berths. Now Redruth and I were to get two of them and Mr. Arrow and the captain were to sleep on deck in the companion, which had been enlarged on each side till you might almost have called it a round-house. Very low it was still, of course; but there was room to swing two hammocks, and even the mate seemed pleased with the arrangement. Even he, perhaps, had been doubtful as to the crew, but that is only guess, for as you shall hear, we had not long the benefit of his opinion.
